pullRequest.body:
From the TestingLowerBounds project.
Co-authored-by: Lorenzo Luccioli

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

This will be used in #21053 to define the KL divergence.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [40bd990466](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21901/commits/40bd990466807d18033c65cef7656ccddb4a88e4)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.InformationTheory.KullbackLeibler.KLFun` (new file)|2079|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ continuous_klFun`
`+ convexOn_Ioi_klFun`
`+ convexOn_klFun`
`+ deriv_klFun`
`+ hasDerivAt_klFun`
`+ integrable_klFun_rnDeriv_iff`
`+ integrable_rnDeriv_mul_log_iff`
`+ integral_klFun_rnDeriv`
`+ integral_rnDeriv_mul_log`
`+ isMinOn_klFun`
`+ klFun`
`+ klFun_apply`
`+ klFun_eq_zero_iff`
`+ klFun_nonneg`
`+ klFun_one`
`+ klFun_zero`
`+ leftDeriv_klFun`
`+ leftDeriv_klFun_one`
`+ leftDeriv_mul_log`
`+ llr_self`
`+ measurable_klFun`
`+ not_differentiableAt_klFun_zero`
`+ not_differentiableWithinAt_klFun_Iio_zero`
`+ not_differentiableWithinAt_klFun_Ioi_zero`
`+ rightDeriv_klFun`
`+ rightDeriv_klFun_one`
`+ rightDeriv_mul_log`
`+ strictConvexOn_klFun`
`+ stronglyMeasurable_klFun`
`+ tendsto_deriv_mul_log_atTop`
`+ tendsto_klFun_atTop`
`+ tendsto_log_nhdsWithin_zero_left`
`+ tendsto_rightDeriv_klFun_atTop`
`+ tendsto_rightDeriv_mul_log_atTop`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

The reason for the statements about the right derivative is that in a future series of PRs I intend to add the theory of f-divergences, which are divergences between measures with value `âˆ« x, f (Î¼.rnDeriv Î½ x).toReal âˆ‚Î½` plus a term that depends on the limit of the right derivative of `f` at infinity.
For the divergence to have nice properties, the function `f` needs to be convex, non-negative with minimum 0 at 1. However we don't want to require that `f` is differentiable (at 1, in particular). The total variation divergence is an example of an f-divergence with `f x = |x - 1|/2`. The right derivative of such a function is a non-decreasing right-continuous function (a Stieltjes function in Mathlib terminology) and will also be used to define a measure.

My point with all those remarks is that the right derivative is a major player in that theory, and if I want to get properties of the KL by saying that it's an f-divergence, I will benefit from having convenience lemmas about the right derivative of `klFun`.

Thanks!
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by EtienneC30.

:v: RemyDegenne can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13524887941/job/37792810430)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13524887941/job/37792810917)
bors d+
I see, that makes sense! Here are two more suggestions.

That's nice. I have one question though, do you really need all those statements about left and right derivatives? I am not sure about the mathlib policy here, but it seems to me that those should not be specialized statements. In particular because in this case the left and right derivatives are in fact true derivatives, I don't see in which case you would need it.
I see, that makes sense! Here are two more suggestions.
bors d+

```suggestion
For probability measures, any function `f` that differs from `klFun` by an affine function would give
```
Is that true? If I take `f = klFun + 1` the integral won't be the same, I will get a plus one. Maybe you mean any affine function of the form `x => a(x - 1)`?
You're right, that's the form I had in mind. I'll fix the text.
Why don't you make the `MeasurableSpace` argument an instance argument?

For the lemmas to work, the `MeasurableSpace` has to be the one on which the measures are defined. If I use an instance argument, the measures have to be defined on the default measurable space of the type. If I use as I do an implicit argument, I can also apply the lemmas to a measure on a sub-sigma-algebra, defined with `Measure.trim`.

In general, whenever there is a measure, `MeasurableSpace` should be implicit.
I see. Am I right in thinking that this principle is not applied in many places of Mathlib? Should this be enforced in future PRs ?

I wrote several PRs to apply that principle to existing files (the latest one was #21907), and enforce it in review when I don't forget. I encourage you to do it as well!
But I also regularly find places that use instance arguments together with measures.
This is also true for `x=0` since it is not differentiable there. Can you generalize please? Same for the two results below.
This is therefore a true equality.
Maybe you can factor out `IsMinOn klFun (Ici 0) 1`.

You can also use `simpa` here. The same is true for many `simp only` + `exact` in the file, pick the version you prefer.
```suggestion
  simpa using not_DifferentiableAt_log_mul_zero
```

You can do things the other way around to simplify a bit the proofs:
```suggestion
lemma isMinOn_klFun : IsMinOn klFun (Ici 0) 1 :=
  convexOn_klFun.isMinOn_of_rightDeriv_eq_zero (by simp) (by simp)

/-- The function `klFun` is nonnegative on `[0,âˆž)`. -/
lemma klFun_nonneg (hx : 0 â‰¤ x) : 0 â‰¤ klFun x := klFun_one â–¸ isMinOn_klFun hx
```
Why an `abbrev` and not a `def` here?
I don't remember what motivated that choice and I don't see any good reason now. I turned it into a def.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: define klFun, auxiliary function used for the Kullback-Leibler divergence

source.title: feat(InformationTheory): define the Kullback-Leibler divergence between two finite measures
